text.p: Following are some of the leading stories in the Swedish papers this morning. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- A survey of 50 primary schools across the country found there was a big difference between the standard of schools with differences in Swedish and English skills particularly noticeable.

- Sweden's umbrella trade union organisation LO wants the government to call a new referendum on the country's nuclear industry and proposed phase out. LO claims the agreement between the ruling Social Democrats and Centre and Left parties to close one of 12 nuclear reactors in 1998 and another in 2001 is not in line with the results of a 1980 referendum in which people wanted to close the whole industry.

- Handelsbanken's bid for mortgage bank Stadshypotek ends on Friday this week and the large bank needs to win 90 percent of shares for the deal to proceed. A bank spokesman says it is important that people reply quickly. No details of the level of response were given.
- Consultancy firms FFNS and VBB are merging, the companies announced on Monday. They said the merger would boost expansion and help lift overseas business to 25 percent in the next 10 years.
- People talking on mobile telephones while driving have a four times higher chance of having a car accident than they otherwise would, a study from Canada shows.
- Swedish authorities are successfully cracking down on companies avoiding taxes by opearating via off-shore tax havens.
- Swedish unions umbrella organisation LO is considering sueing convenience store chain 7-Eleven over the hours its employees may work as well as what products it can sell during the night.

- Several Swedish unions have substantially lowered their expectations for wages increases with inflation holding steady at record low levels. An important benchmark agreement was that signed by the paperworkers union which provided a 2.6 percent wage rise. The bank and insurance workers' union has lowered its demand for a wage hike to 3.5 percent from 4.5 percent.

- There has been a dramatic increase in the number of companies registerered in Stockholm which have links to Russia and the Baltic states. Police inspector Bjorn Larsson said research shows that Russian and Baltic economic interests are involved in 500 companies in Stockholm. Many of these companies are in real estate, business development and consulting or import and exports of oil, minerals, gold, cars and antiques. He said Stockholm has become popular to launder dirty money.

- The Carnegie investment bank and brokerage, which was bought from Nordbanken by Singer & Friedland of the UK several years ago, is moving its headquarters from London back to Stockholm. The company recently divested its operations in Spain and on Friday sold its Portuguese unit to Merrill Lynch.

- Industrial investments in Sweden will decline by six percent this year, breaking a trend of three years of steady increases, according to an economic forecast by Industriforbundet, the Confederation of Swedish Industry. Last year industrial investments increased by about 14 percent.
